remarked: Grade: 83 (First Class Honours);Exhibited at the University of Melbourne's designX
overview: Drop It Off was created as my Final Capstone Project for my Bachelor’s degree in UX Design at the University of Melbourne. Our team of five UX designers was tasked with identifying a real-world problem, conceptualizing a digital solution, and developing a prototype. We conducted user research, usability testing, and iterative design evaluations to refine our solution.
para0: div[{H1[Drop It Off]}{p-em[What if donating was as easy as throwing something away? Drop It Off makes donating an effortless experience by connecting unwanted items with people who actually need them—reducing landfill waste in the process.]}],h3[The challenge],p[In a culture of constant consumption, people frequently discard unwanted items—but without clear donation guidelines, many default to landfill disposal or indiscriminately dump everything in donation bins, leading to overflow and wasted items at large charities. At the same time, smaller NGOs struggle with visibility and lack a structured way to communicate when and what they can accept. Without a system to streamline donations, valuable resources go to waste, and organisations miss out on essential support.],h3[Our solution],div[{p[Drop It Off bridges this gap by creating a donation-matching system that:]}{ul.col[Matches donors with NGOs actively seeking specific items through a filterable map.;Guides users with an AI-powered photo-scan that determines whether an item is fit for donation.;Increases visibility for smaller NGOs, helping donors find causes that align with their values.]}{p[These are all key functions of the app that helps diverting reusable items from landfills by making the donation process an effortless experience and seamless as disposal.]}],h3[Impact summary],div[{p[By making donating as seamless as disposal, Drop It Off has the potential to reduce consumer waste, improve resource distribution, and support NGOs in need. The platform’s impact extends across multiple stakeholders, creating both environmental and social benefits:]}{ul.col[Validated Usability & Real-World Feasibility —71.4 SUS Score indicates strong usability after the first design iteration.;User-Centric Design —Iterative testing and stakeholder insights ensure the platform meets real-world needs.;Scalable Impact  —NGO and business-facing integration enhances widespread engagement and long-term viability.]}]
para2: h2[Research & Discovery],div[{p[We first identified consumer waste as our situation of use, focusing on why donations were being misdirected or discarded. To map out key influences in this ecosystem, we established five main stakeholder groups:]}{ul.col[Consumers: Individuals trying to donate items or discard them.;Charity Workers & NGOs: Organisations managing donations but facing logistical challenges.;People in Need: Beneficiaries reliant on donations for essential items.;Circular Economy Services: Platforms facilitating second-hand sales and exchanges.;Retail Industry: Businesses generating surplus items with potential for donation.]}{p[To ensure high usefulness, we conducted interviews with representatives across three of these groups, using their insights to refine our assumptions and identify critical pain points.]}],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP0a-stakeholders-main.jpg{main stakeholders in the situation of consumer waste;The initial rich picture, captioning the main stakeholders: consumers, retail industry (consumer industry), charity workers, people in need, and circular economy services.}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP0b-rich-picture.jpg{rich picture;Initial rich picture with assumptions of the stakeholders’ needs and wants with annotated complimentary— and clashing statements (red and green lines).}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP0c-stakeholders.jpg{nuanced map of stakeholders;A more nuanced map of all the stakeholders, with annotations on who we interviewed.}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP2-rich-picture.png{detailed, final rich picture;Detailed rich picture with overview of stakeholders’ presumed and observed wants and needs with annotated complimentary and clashing statements.}]}]
para3: Div[{h2[Initial Ideation and Prototyping]}{p[After identifying the stakeholders clashing and complimenting wants and pain points, each team member developed concepts to address specific paradoxes in the donation system.]}{p[These concepts got evaluated on their usefulness by 5 different stakeholders, and based on these new insights, we decided to merge three of them: The donation platform, an AI item scanner, and an information channel on sustainably riddance of items.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/ideation.png{initial ideation prototypes}]}],div[{h3[The Donation Platform —highest ranked for usefulness]}{p[Businesses and consumers seek a fast, effortless way to donate, but slow communication and processing at donation centers cause delays and lost contributions. Without structured intake systems, valuable items are discarded instead of reaching those in need.]}{p[The platform streamlines this process by matching donations to centers actively seeking them with a minimalistic filter by category system. Users tick off what they want to donate, which instantly updates the map—and list view to show nearby drop-off locations.]}],div.small-gallery[{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP3-design-ideas01.png{donation platform low fidelity prototype}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP3-design-ideas012.png{donation platform low fidelity prototype}]}],div[{h3[The AI Scanner —Eliminates Uncertainty for Donors]}{p[Donors want a fast way to give away items but often struggle to determine what’s donation-worthy, while donation centers face an influx of unsuitable goods, slowing processing.]}{p[The AI Scanner solves this by instantly assessing items through image recognition, guiding users on whether to donate, recycle, or dispose. This reduces uncertainty, prevents wasted drop-offs, and ensures donation centers receive only what they can use.]}],div.small-gallery-tall[{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP3-design-ideas2.jpg]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP3-design-ideas2b.jpg]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP3-design-ideas2c.jpg]}], div[{h3[Information Channel —Knowledge to Encourage Responsible Disposal]}{p[Many consumers want to donate or recycle but hesitate due to uncertainty about whether their items are wanted or useful for others. As a result, impatience often outweighs the desire to help, leading items to end up in landfills.]}{p[The information channel aims to provide clear, accessible guidance on how to dispose of unwanted goods sustainably. Users can search for an item, and the app offers instructions on whether to donate or recycle.]}],div.small-gallery[{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP3-design-ideas3.jpg{information channel low fidelity prototype}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP3-design-ideas3b.jpg{information channel low fidelity prototype}]}]
para4: h2.multi-h3s[User Insights for Design Decisions],div[{h3[Personas and Textual Scenarios]}{p[We developed personas and textual scenarios that each represented our key stakeholders to guide our design decisions and ensure their needs and wants were met in our final design.]}],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP6-Personas.png{Table overview of personas;Overview of the created personas, and how they inform the design process.}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP6-Persona01.png{persona;Luna Abimola, a NGO worker based on insights from interviews on how they work. Informed us on what info they have and are able to communicate to possible donors.}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP6-Persona01-textual-scenario.png{textual scenario;Textual Scenario explaining Luna's hectic work life. Gives indication on what type of information they would need from the donors, what type of info the can update possible donors on, and emphasises how much time they can afford to update these databases.}]}],div[{h3[User Flow]}{p[Using the information from the textual scenarios, we created a quick user journey flow which mapped out all the screens we needed to prototype in order to properly test the high-fi prototype.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP7-User-journey-flow.jpg{user joruney flow;A user journey flow that outlines the steps consumers take to dispose of their unwanted goods.}]}{h3[Low Fidelity Prototypes]}{p[Below I've included some of our low fidelity prototypes of Drop it Off's interface designs.]}],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP8-lofi-prototypes-landing-mobile.jpg{low fidelity prototype of drop it off;Drop it off landing page (mobile) wireframes illustrating interaction flow.}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP8-lofi-prototypes-landing-desktop.jpg{low fidelity prototype drop it off;Drop it off landing page (desktop) wireframes with interaction— and usability annotations}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/STEP8-lofi-prototype-scanner.jpg{low fidelity prototype drop it off;Low fidelity prototype of the scanning function (we ended up going for the one on the right).}]}]
para5: h2.multi-h3s[Final Design],div[{h3[Usability Design Rationale]}{p[As our aim with Drop it Off is to shift people's default mindset toward disposing of unwanted items, the final design needed to make the process as effortless as possible. To achieve this we focused on three key usability heuristics:]}{ul.col[Recognition over Recall;Flexibility and Efficiency of Use;Consistency of Standards.]}],div[{h3[Final Prototype]}{p[In the final prototype, the main interaction is based on a filter system with large icons, making it easy for users to quickly identify the appropriate category for their donation items, altering the possible drop off locations. We introduced a flexible list view to accommodate different user needs and implemented multiple item entry options—allowing users to add donation items via the filtration system, search or the AI scanner. The design follows familiar interface standards, minimising the user's cognitive load and making their experience seamless.]}],div.prototypes-mobile[{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/prototype/onboarding-reduce.png{onboarding screen;Onboarding (what we do) 01.}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/prototype/onboarding-reuse.png{onboarding screen;Onboarding (what we do) 02.}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/prototype/onboarding-recycle.png{onboarding screen;Onboarding (what we do) 03.}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/prototype/onboarding-items.png{onboarding screen;Onboarding (user inserts data for customised sorting for relevant information articles)}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/prototype/onboarding-cause.png{onboarding screen;Onboarding (user inserts data for customised sorting for relevant information articles)}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/prototype/landing.png{landing page screen;landing page (mobile)}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/prototype/landing02-fashion.png{landing page screen;Landing page, user filter system to only show drop off location accepting all fashion & wearables}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/prototype/landing03-shoes.png{landing page screen;User broadens the search for charities/organisations accepting shoe donations}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/prototype/scan.png{AI scanning item screen;AI scanning interface after clicking on the camera icon}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/prototype/scan-assess.png{AI scan assessing item screen;AI assessed the trousers as unfit for donation due to holes, gives user option to correct the assessement (in case of wrong assessement)}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/prototype/scan-correct01.png{AI scan item screen;User presented with option to correct the assessement}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/prototype/scan-correct02.png{AI scan item screen;User corrects AI assessement}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/prototype/landing04-sports-map.png{landing page screen;User extends search for possible drop off location by adding 'Sports and Outdoors' and 'Sports Equipment' filters}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/prototype/landing05-sports-list.png{landing page screen;Possible drop off locations in list view}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/prototype/landing06-sports-list-filter.png{landing page screen;Possible drop off locations in filtered list view, now only showing places accepting all the items user wants to donate}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/prototype/inform.png{organisation information screen;Information on the organisation who wants your item (what they do +contact information}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/prototype/inform02.png{information article screen;Information article with video instruction option to written content.}]}]
para6: h2[Observational User Evaluation],p[We conducted the evaluation with five participants representing different types of donors –including two familiar with the app, all with varying donation routines confirmed in the pre-test questions.],p[Participants then completed seven task scenarios, allowing us to observe how they navigated the prototype, interacted with key features, and experienced the current layout. Afterward, they answered nine task-related questions to provide qualitative insights and validate observations, followed by seven user experience questions to gather quantitative feedback on usability and user experience.],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/user-eval-table.png{table overview;Table overview of wide demographic participants who took part in the observational evaluation.}]}{img[assets/proj/dropitoff/methods/user-eval-task-score.png{Individual task score table;Overview of tasks, their average ratings on how intuitive each participant found the task (1 = not intuitive, 5 = very intuitive), and what key feature they tested. Data gives insight on prototype's current usability and reflects overall positive user experience.}]}],div[{h3[Key Insights]}{ul.col[71.4 SUS Score —A slightly above-average usability score, showing promise after the first design iteration of the final design concept.;Flexible Design — Users found the filtering system intuitive and liked having control over selecting drop-off locations based on specific donation needs.;Useful Dual Map/List View — Participants valued both the map view for its quick visual overview, and the list view was preferred when they needed detailed location information.;Intuitive Tagging System — Users felt the icons and labels made categorizing items easy, reducing effort in selecting the right donation category.;Low Visibility & Usability for AI Scanner – Participants struggled to find and effectively use the scanning feature.]}]
para7: div[{h2[Risk Assessement]}{p[While Drop It Off has strong usability potential, certain risks must be addressed to ensure long-term success and sustained engagement across stakeholders.]}{h3[Consumer Engagement & Behavior Change]}{p[→Users may default to landfill disposal if the platform is unintuitive or requires too much effort.]}{p[Possible solution: Refine onboarding, AI scanner visibility, and donation flow guidance to reinforce behavior change.]}{h3[NGO Participation]}{p[→For the system to work, NGOs must actively update donation needs and storage capacity. Without engagement, the database risks becoming outdated or incomplete.]}{p[Possible solution: Ensure seamless user flow and develop reminder systems to encourage and remind user of consistent updates.]}{h3[Storage Limitations for Businesses]}{p[→Businesses may lack the time to contact multiple NGOs individually, and available storage capacity varies across organizations, making large-scale donations difficult to coordinate.]}{p[Possible solution: Improve communication by adding a 'Large Donation Accepted' indicator on NGO profiles and providing direct contact options for businesses to coordinate bulk donations and storage.]}],h2[What Next?],p[While the current iteration of Drop It Off has shown promising usability results, several areas require further refinement to enhance user experience. Moving forewards,  using lean UX methods iteratively with rapid prototyping, and co-creation workshops with stakeholders will be key in refining Drop It Off for its next phase.],div[{h3[Improving AI Scanner Visibility]}{p[User testing revealed that many participants struggled to find and use the AI scanner—some were unaware of its full functionality. Future iterations should focus on making the scanner more prominent within the user flow and refining feedback mechanisms to help users understand its value.]}],div[{h3[Enhancing Onboarding & Discoverability]}{p[Users requested clearer first-time guidance, especially regarding item categorization and the AI scanner. A tutorial or onboarding walkthrough could improve user adoption by ensuring they understand how to navigate the app and use key features effectively.]}],div[{h3[Expanding NGO & Business Integration]}{p[The NGO and business-facing interface is critical for Drop It Off to function at all—without it, there would be no populated donation database, rendering the donor-side ineffective. The next iteration must focus on developing a streamlined inventory and storage management system, ensuring efficiency and ease of use for NGOs, whose daily operations are often fast-paced and resource-limited.]}],div[{h3[Scaling Usability Testing for Broader Insights]}{p[Future iterations must include testing with a larger, more diverse participant pool—particularly NGO representatives and high-volume donors—to validate the platform's real-world functionality and identify further refinements.]}]
para8: div.reflection[{h1[Reflection]}{p[It was really fun to work on Drop It Off over the 14 weeks, not just because of the insights it gave me into the design thinking process, but also because it became a passion project. Designing an app with potential for real social and environmental impact made the process even more exciting —it became something I could imagine  actually coming together and existing in reality*, which made me even more motivated to make it as useful and usable as possible.]}{p[Academically, it was fascinating to see  how using real user insights to shape the app's design decisions firsthand, and how they inherently improved usability and user experience, making Drop It Off a truly functional and valuable product.]}{p-em[*hmu if you're keen to make this happen too;))]}{h2[If I did this again...]}{p[Instead of waiting for a final prototype evaluation, I would have involved users earlier and more frequently throughout each design iteration (e.g., landing page, AI scanner). Testing key interactions as soon as wireframes took shape would have surfaced usability issues sooner and refined navigation and feature discoverability earlier in the process.]}{p[Additionally, as a team of five UX designers, we could have leveraged our resources more effectively by creating multiple low-fidelity prototypes for key features (e.g., onboarding flows, scanner integration, filtering systems). Presenting these variations in A/B testing would have provided clearer user insights, ultimately leading to a stronger usability foundation for the final design.]}]

remarked: Final Capstone Project for my Bachelor’s degree in Graphic Design at the University of Melbourne;Exhibited at the Victoria College of Art End of Year Exhibition
tools: Visual Studio Code;Adobe Photoshop;Adobe InDesign;Adobe Premiere Pro
overview: Final capstone project in Graphic Design in ___ of a padssion project, focusing on...

roles: UX & Service Designer;Conversational Design Architect;Technical Lead;Project Lead
overview: Developed as part of my Bachelor’s degree in UX Design at the University of Melbourne, UniAdventures was a team-driven project focused on designing a hybrid service—blending physical and digital touchpoints, including a chatbot—to enhance student well-being through domestic travel. Through user research, iterative prototyping, and accessibility-focused design, we ensured the service was inclusive, engaging, and practical for diverse student needs.
para0: div[{h1[UniAdventures]}{p-em[How can service and conversational design make student travel more accessible? Over nine weeks, we designed and tested UniAdventures—an integrated service that simplifies domestic travel for students through structured trips, on-campus consultations, and a chatbot-driven digital platform.]}{h3[The challenge]}{p[Students want to explore Australia, but financial barriers, accessibility challenges, and a lack of guidance hold them back. Without structured support, many miss out on valuable travel experiences.]}{h3[Our solution]}{p[UniAdventures is a multi-touchpoint service designed to make domestic travel more affordable, accessible, and socially engaging.]}{ul.col[University-run group trips —Three structured trips per year to encourage community-building and cost-effective travel;On-campus travel consultation service —Students can book appointments for trip planning, gear hire, and club activity information.;Digital platform with chatbot integration —Provides trip recommendations, booking assistance, and a student forum to foster engagement.]}]
para2: div[{h2[User-Centered Design & Iterative Prototyping]}{h3[Defining Core User Needs]}{p[To ensure the service aligned with student needs, we analyzed persona insights provided in the university’s research pack. This confirmed key priorities]}{ul.col[Affordability & convenience —Students need low-cost travel options that fit into their academic schedules.;Social engagement & accessible —The service should foster social interaction and friendship while accommodating students with disabilities.]}{h3[Iterative Prototyping & Testing]}{p[We conducted weekly feedback sessions using Co-Creative Workshops and Wizard of Oz Approaches to iteratively test prototypes with our target users. These sessions provided real-time insights, helping us refine usability, accessibility, and key service touchpoints through:]}{ul.col[Storyboards —Visualizing user interactions.;Desktop Walkthrough —Testing physical service touchpoints.;User Joourney Map —Defining key interactions and accessibility requirements.;Wireframes –Structuring the digital experience with accessibility in mind.;Flow Chart –Structuring chatbot logic.;Logical Data Model –Defining API connections and workflows.]}]
para3: H2[Ideation Process],div[{p[We used Miro to map out key user needs (from our research pack) and generate ‘How Might We’ statements for each. As a team, we conducted a 10x10 ideation exercise, refining ideas based on user feedback. We then prioritized these in an Idea Portfolio, evaluating each for usability and feasibility.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/uni-adventure/miro-sketches.png{post it notes;Collaborative digital pin-up board—documenting user needs, ‘How Might We’ statements, and a 10x10 idea generation exercise, followed by user feedback and feasibility ranking in an Idea Portfolio.}]}{h3[Final Problem Statement and Service Scope]}{p-em[“How might we facilitate low-budget trips that require minimal effort for students who seek new friends and new experiences?”]}{p[After finalizing our problem statement, we workshopped possible service attributes that would best support student needs. Feedback revealed that students preferred structured yet flexible travel opportunities that promote social engagement while maintaining independence.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/uni-adventure/howMW2.jpg{whiteboard with meeting notes;Early project meeting—exploring service scopes, balancing self-organized trips with structured travel, and integrating club activities into the service.}]}]
para4: div[{h2[Service Touchpoints Prototyping]}{h3[Storyboarding]}{p[I drew up two storyboards for the team to visualise and communicate the service in the first feedback session, depicting how the personas would benefit and use UniAdventures.]}{p[Initially, the team had concerns about the service being too broad were disproved through user feedback, which validated our approach. Moving forewards, we focused on Mei’s journey, incorporating elements from Ashwyn’s to ensure a balanced experience.]}],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/uni-adventure/storyboard-main.png{storyboard;Storyboard illustrating how one of our personas, Mei, would experience and use uniAdventures, taking her social anxiety to accordance as well as her want to explore the new country she is studying in and her lifetime goal of seeing a koala.}]}{img[assets/proj/uni-adventure/storyboard.png{storyboard;Storyboard illustrating how our other persona, Ashwyn, would benefit and want to use our service, with focus on wanting to try new things like rock climbing.}]}],div[{h3[Desktop Walkthrough]}{p[We prepared a desktop walkthrough for an hour before applying a Wizard-of-Oz approach with a group of potential users to play through the service and figure out what was working and what was missing with the physical components, as well as the concept for our service.]}{p[To get valuable insights, we directed the participants with background information and context of our primary persona who had social anxiety, and the disabilities that were specified in the client brief. We had the participants role-play as the personas and themselves while we acted out the staff.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/uni-adventure/desktop-wt.jpg{desktop walkthrough}]}],div[{h3[User Journey Map]}{p[I shared the task of creating the user journey map with another team member, where she established the relevant steps, and I added the emotion graph and thoughts, contact points, accessibility notes, evidence, and further service opportunities.]}{p[This exercise helped us identify overlooked details, such as accessibility needs and accommodations for social anxiety. Mapping the journey provided a clearer design overview and highlighted areas for improved inclusivity.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/uni-adventure/user-journey.png]}],div[{h3[Wireframes]}{p[Our wireframes evolved through multiple iterations, shaped by team discussions and weekly feedback sessions with students.]}{p[The wireframes are annotated for accessibility, which, if this were to become an actual service, would help streamline the developing process.]}],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/uni-adventure/Homepage.png{hi-fi wireframe;Home page high fidelity wireframe/prototype with accessibility annotations for development.}]}{img[assets/proj/uni-adventure/Forum.png{hi-fi wireframe;Travel forum high fidelity wireframe/prototype with accessibility annotations for development.}]}{img[assets/proj/uni-adventure/booking02.png{hi-fi wiremframe;Booking page high fidelity wireframe/prototype with accessibility annotations for development.}]}{img[assets/proj/uni-adventure/booking.png{hi-fi wiremframe;Booking-information page high fidelity wireframe/prototype with accessibility annotations for development.}]}]
para5: div[{h2[Conversational Design Process]}{p[We designed a chatbot to make trip-planning effortless—guiding students through recommendations, booking, and travel FAQs seamlessly.]}{h3[Flow chart]}{p[After determining the chatbot’s objectives, I led the creation of the flowchart, mapping out potential dialogues and decision trees..]}{p[I performed a one-on-one Wizard-of-Oz session, during which a potential user and I walked through the different workflows to try to spot gaps in the model and unclear messaging & user prompts.]}],div.multi-carousel [{img[assets/proj/uni-adventure/flowchart.png{flowchart;Flowchart mapping out all possible talking points between user and the conversational agent.}]}{img[assets/proj/uni-adventure/flowchart-closeup.png{flowchart closeup;Closeup of the flowchart. Yellow box = chat output, filled green oval = user selected button, green outline oval = buttons, black outlined diamond = computer calculates.}]}],div[{h3[Logical Data Model]}{p[To make the job easier in Voiceflow, I created a logical data model to map out what information would be necessary for the different APIs and workflows. This will make the VoiceFlow implementation easier, streamlining the making of the datasets and the workflows themselves (with functional use of variables and API connections)]}{img.solo[assets/proj/uni-adventure/logicalDataModel.png{logical data model/Logical Data Model illustrating the different data models of information that the conversational agent will need access too, and how they connect with each other.}]}],div[{h3[Agent persona]}{p[The team established a soft persona for the conversational agent aiming to create a welcoming and persanolised student-computer interaction, while maintaining a clear distinction that the agent is an AI and not an actual person. The factors we considered were:]}{ul.col[Theme and context of adventure and travel;Professional and polite language;Concise and clear communication for a broad audience]}],div[]
para6: h2[Final Design],p[You can test the chatbot {a[here;https://shakibatavan.github.io/GeronimoHost/]} or have a look at the demonstration done by my team associate, Shakiba:],iframe.solo[<iframe width='1206' height='678' src='https://www.youtube.com/embed/x4KEnak_Hr4' title='Geronimo Prototype demonstration' frameborder='0' allow='accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share' referrerpolicy='strict-origin-when-cross-origin' allowfullscreen></iframe>]
para7: div.reflection[{h1[Reflection]}{p[Overall, I think this project has been perfect in terms of learning how the different methods can be used. Looking back, there are things I would change, but for a first attempt at service design, I am happy about the team’s process for the past six weeks and the outcome.]}{h2[If I did this again...]}{p[I would have been better prepared for the feedback sessions. Some of the earlier ones spent more time on the team presenting and explaining the design instead of presenting and listening. Ideally, there would have been more iterations both throughout the semester and continuing (if this was to be an actual project). However, with the intent of learning, I am pretty content with UniAdventures.]}]

overview: Designing a digital type specimen for Keiner, a geometric sans-serif by Alfredo Marco Pradil. The goal was to create an interactive and conceptual showcase that presents Keiner’s tone, technical range, and functional versatility to a digital-first audience.
para0: div[{h1[Online Type Specimen]}{p-em[What if ...]}],h3[Keiner],p[Keiner was designed by Alfredo Marco Pradil for Hanken Design Co. — a digital design company and type foundry.],h3[The problem],p[The current specimen is visually clean and balanced, but lacks interactivity. It doesn’t fully give designers the tools they need to see how it performs in different contexts.],h3[My Solution],p[A web-based, interactive specimen that lets designers test Keiner across layouts, sizes, and languages — directly in the browser. Built on a strict grid, but sprinkled with playful interactions that reflect Keiner’s quirky, characterful details and the fun spirit of the web.],h3[Impact],p[The result is a more engaging and accessible way to experience Keiner. It allows potential clients to evaluate how the typeface performs across different use cases, improving confidence in their decision — and increasing the likelihood of purchase. If Keiner isn’t the right fit, the experience still showcases the foundry’s design quality, leading users to explore other fonts in their catalogue.]
para2: h2[Current Design],p[The current type specimen is balanced and clean, showcasing the typeface's versaitlity and characteristics. However it lacks interactivity and engagement with their target audience and potential buyers.],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/keiner/ts01.png{current type specimen cover;current type specimen cover}]}{img[assets/proj/keiner/ts02.png{current type specimen cover;current type specimen cover}]}{img[assets/proj/keiner/ts03.png{current type specimen cover;current type specimen cover}]}{img[assets/proj/keiner/ts04.png{current type specimen cover;current type specimen cover}]}{img[assets/proj/keiner/ts05.png{current type specimen cover;current type specimen cover}]}]
para3: h2[Research],p[I studied interactive type specimens like Neue Regrade and Fontshare to understand how type is shown online. Combined with functionalist ideas from Warde and Bayer, this led to a minimal, grid-based layout that matches Keiner’s geometric structure and precise tone.],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/keiner/inspirations/func01.png{book;Beatrice Warde – The Crystal Goblet: I treated the interface like a clear goblet: pared-back and functional, so the typeface could shine without distraction.}]}{img[assets/proj/keiner/inspirations/func02.png{universal type specimen; Herbert Bayer – Bauhaus functionalism: Bayer’s reductionist, modular principles influenced the grid system and visual restraint in the specimen’s layout.}]}{img[assets/proj/keiner/inspirations/nrm.png{digital specimen;Neue Regrade by Márk József Ungvári — digital specimen reference}]}{img[assets/proj/keiner/inspirations/fs.png{typefoundry;Fontshare.com — typefoundry and editorial testing reference: Possible to edit and change type size, line height etc. for each type.}]}]
para4: h2[Developmental Work],div[{h3[The concept]}{p[Keiner’s design is strict but versatile — mono-linear and geometric, yet flexible across styles and languages. The specimen mirrors this through a rigid grid system with interactive, playful touches. The colour scheme reinforces this balance: black and white for clarity, RGB blue for digital precision and functional tone.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/keiner/dev_scans_Page_1.png{notes; Sketching out how Keiner’s rigid structure and global reach could translate into a clean, interactive web experience with subtle playful details.}]}],h3[Sketches and Implementation],p[I started with hand-drawn sketches and wireframes to define layout, flow and interaction states. These guided the development process, where I built the specimen from scratch using HTML, CSS and JavaScript — annotating the code and refining interactions as I went.],div.small-gallery[{img[assets/proj/keiner/dev_scans_Page_4.png{notes;}]}{img[assets/proj/keiner/dev_scans_Page_5.png{notes;}]}{img[assets/proj/keiner/dev_scans_Page_6.png{notes;}]}{img[assets/proj/keiner/dev_scans_Page_7.png{notes;}]}]

remarked: Grade: 84 (First Class Honours);Exhibited at the Victoria College of Art End of Year Exhibition;Exhibited at the University of Melbourne designX
overview: An intensive five-week rebrand of OAK, a staple in Australia's flavoured milk market. Through rapid iterations, competitive analysis, and strategic positioning, me and my team of 3 other graphic designers transformed OAK’s visual identity to engage a younger demographic and stand out on the crowded beverage shelf.
para0: div[{h1[OAK Rebrand: Energizing a Flavoured Milk Icon]}{p-em[What if flavoured milk packed the same punch as an energy drink? Our OAK rebrand reinvents this Aussie staple with a bold new identity—designed to stand out, excite younger consumers, and dominate the beverage aisle.]}],div[{h3[The challenge]}{p[Despite being a household name since 1967, OAK struggles with brand perception and consumption habits. Flavoured milk is seen as an occasional treat, limiting repeat purchases. Its brash, masculine branding has also alienated a broader audience, especially after past campaigns faced backlash for being overly aggressive. In a market crowded with competitors like Farmers Union, Dairy Farmers, Dare, and Big M, OAK needs a refreshed identity that modernizes its image, increases accessibility, and goes beyond nostalgia.]}{h3[Our solution]}{ul.col[Refreshed Brand Positioning —A bold yet inclusive identity that broadens OAK’s appeal while retaining its high-energy personality.;New packaging formats —Diversified product range with bottles for convenience, cartons for nostalgia, and pouches for efficiency.;Re-Launch Strategy  —Eye-catching visuals to grab attention, balanced with familiar elements to maintain brand trust.]}{h3[Impact Summary]}{p[A refreshed OAK rebrand has the potential to transform its market presence by:]}{ul.col[Increasing Consumption Frequency –Reframing OAK as an energy-packed, everyday drink.;Enhancing Shelf Visibility —A fresh, dynamic design that stands out in a competitive market.;Broadening Appeal —Moving away from aggressive masculinity to a more inclusive, high-energy identity.]}]
para2: h2[OAK today],p[OAK has long positioned itself as a bold, full-flavoured milk brand, balancing its established legacy with a loud, brash, and masculine identity designed to grab attention. While this approach reinforces familiarity and nostalgia, it also creates barriers to broader market appeal and feeds into their existing challenges.],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/oak/current-brand.jpg{packaging design analysis;Packaging design analysis highlighting OAK's main selling point of nostalgia and being full on flavour.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/current-brand-shelf.jpg{various packaging designs;Overview of all OAK products available in the supermarkets}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/current-brand-voice.jpg{brand voice analysis;Their current brand voice is highly masculine and loud.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/current-brand-values.jpg{brand values;OAK brand values}]}]
para3: h2[Competitive & Market Research],h3[Market Research & Analysis],p[With a growing emphasis on health-conscious choices, young consumers are increasingly prioritizing nutritious, on-the-go beverages. As a result, demand for flavoured milk is rising, positioning it as a strong competitor to carbonated drinks (Market Research Future, 2023). To meet this shift, flavoured milk brands are adapting their packaging to be more portable, visually appealing, and youth-oriented, aligning with evolving consumer preferences. Otherwise, urban consumers are drawn to its nutritional benefits and extended shelf life, making it a preferred alternative.],div[{p[Notes for rebrand:]}{ul.col[Match Energy Drinks & Iced Coffee —Bold branding & dynamic packaging.;Prioritize Packaging Appeal —Ergonomic, portable, multi-format options.;Reposition OAK —From occasional treat to everyday energy boost.]}],h3[Competitive Landscape: Finding the Gap],p[The flavoured milk market is crowded, with brands split between two extremes—either targeting children with playful, literal designs (think splashing milk, cartoon cows) or leaning into a serious, muted aesthetic aimed at mature consumers. While both approaches have their niches, they fail to capture the high-energy, fun, and on-the-go experience that flavoured milk should embody.],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/oak/compets.jpg{graph;Competitive Market Positioning – Mapping flavoured milk brands based on their visual identity, from fun to serious and mellow to energetic.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/compets02.jpg{graph;Youthful vs. Grown-Up Appeal – Analyzing how flavoured milk brands visually target different demographics.}]}]
para4: h2[NEW Brand Positioning],p[OAK’s rebrand balances familiarity with bold reinvention, evolving from a traditionally brash, masculine identity to a cheeky, energetic, and inclusive brand that resonates with a broader audience. While staying true to its full-flavoured heritage, the new OAK introduces playfulness, efficiency, and a modern edge, ensuring it remains relevant to younger consumers.],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/oak/brand-pos.png]}{img[assets/proj/oak/brand-pos-focus.png]}],h2[Target Audience Analysis],div[{h3[Consumption Insights]}{p[Our survey of 401 participants aged 13–34 revealed key insights into flavoured milk consumption habits. While most consumers drink it between meals, preferences for packaging vary—some favor bottles for convenience, others prefer cartons for nostalgia, and some opt for larger jugs at home or sachets for efficiency at the gym.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/oak/audience.png{infographic;A survey of 401 consumers (ages 13–34) shows that most drink flavoured milk between meals, with varied preferences for packaging formats based on convenience and occasion.}]}],h3[Personas],p[The new insights highlighted how people drink flavoured milk in between meals, with meals, after exercise. There are multiple preferences for how they like to consume them, which need to be addressed. To aid in the deisgn deci, we created personas to represent different parts of our target audience],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/oak/persona01.jpg{persona;Sophie represents the sportive student who drinks OAK after practice and in between study sessions.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/persona02.jpg{persona;Andy represents the current main audience of OAK: the tradie who chugs their carton of milk on (their way to/from) the construction site.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/persona03.jpg{persona;Sam represents the nurse with a hectic schedule who needs something quick and nutritious to gulp down when she can't afford to take a proper lunch break.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/persona04.jpg{persona;Ebony represents the (classic) younger part of the audience who looks at flavoured milk as a treat, and gets swayed by social media trends.}]}]
para5: h2[NEW Concept Statement],p[With a focus on delivering bold, enjoyable flavours, OAK continues to bring fun to flavoured milk, but now with an even stronger emphasis on efficiency —helping you stay energised and ready for whatever’s next.],h2[Visual References],p[To reshape OAK’s brand identity, we looked beyond traditional flavoured milk branding and took inspiration from high-energy, engaging product categories that align with the rebrand’s bold, fun, and energetic positioning.],h3[Carbonated (Energy) Drinks],div[{p[Consumers often turn to carbonated (energy) drinks for an instant pick-me-up. By adopting vibrant colours, ergonomic bottles and bold typography, OAK can tap into this high-energy space and reposition itself as a competitive alternative.]}{p[Design Takeaway: Introduce dynamic, grab-and-go packaging that visually reinforces OAK’s energizing effect.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/oak/reference-carb.jpg{shelf of carbonated drinks;Shelf display of different carbonated drinks and their dynamic, colourful and eye catching design elements}]}],h3[Ice Cream Packaging Designs],p[While flavoured milk brands typically use muted, milky tones, ice cream packaging celebrates indulgence with bright, playful colours and engaging visuals. Leaning into vibrant palettes will make OAK stand out on shelves while communicating the joy of drinking flavoured milk.],p[Design Takeaway: Use bold colours & playful branding to shift perception from a basic dairy product to an exciting, flavour-packed drink.],div.small-gallery[{img[assets/proj/oak/reference-ic01.jpg{ice cream designs}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/reference-ic03.jpg {ice cream designs}]}],h3[Comic Books & Onomatopoeia Graphics],p[Comics use high-contrast visuals, exaggerated typography, and action-driven layouts to engage and excite. This style can reinforce OAK’s new cheeky, dynamic personality, and visually communicating the ‘punch’ of flavour that comes with every sip.],p[Design Takeaway: Introduce expressive typography, motion-inspired graphics, and high-impact layouts to reflect OAK’s bold, lively tone.],div.small-gallery[{img[assets/proj/oak/reference-cb02.jpg{onomatopoeia designs}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/reference-cb03.jpg{onomatopoeia designs}]}]
para6: h2[Developmental Process],p[For the duration of this project, the team and I went through weekly feedback sessions with other graphic designers to test the iterative design proposals and how well they matched with our new brand positioning.],div[{h3[Stylesscapes and Label Mockups]}{p[Three of us presented a stylesscape each based on:]}{ul.col[nostalgia (far left);typography heavy (centre); modern playfulness (far right).]}{img.solo[assets/proj/oak/stylesscapes.jpg{stylesscapes;Three stylesscapes with label design suggestions (bottle) and feedback.}]}],h3[Nostalgic Style Exploration],p[Due to its high recognisability (a playful gender neutral, chocolate factory-likeness), the 'nostalgia'-driven design suggestion recieved the best response, and was the one we chose to continue working on],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/oak/dev-nost01.png{label design;First design iteration for nostalgic stylesscape}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/dev-nost02.png{label design;Second design iteration for nostalgic stylesscape}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/dev-nost03.png{label design;Third design iteration for nostalgic stylesscape with minimalist approach}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/dev-nost04.png{label design;Fourth design iteration for nostalgic stylesscape with floating letters}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/dev-nost05.png{label design;Fifth design iteration for nostalgic stylesscape with floating letters and fewer design components}]}],h3[Current Path Not Working],p[As we kept iterating on the nostalgia driven design style, we kept getting stuck in the 'too close to the original only worse' ditch. We tried experimenting with the 'letters floating in choc milk' and completely warp the letterings.],div.small-gallery[{img[assets/proj/oak/dev-nost-EXPL.png{label design;Scans of the current label, warped by moving it over a scanner.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/dev-nost-play.png{label design;New label suggestion (unsuccessful)}]}],p[In the end however, we decided three and a half weeks in to completely change the design direction, and turn back to the {b[modern and playful]} stylesscape. We looked closer at our visual references and explored colourful, punchy yet minimal looks.],div.small-gallery[{img[assets/proj/oak/dev-mod-play.png{label design;Drawing back to the minimalist colourful typography bold and expressive designs from carbonated drinks.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/dev-play.png{label design;Incorporated the punchy comic book like expression.}]}]
para7: h2[Final Designs],h3[Concept Statement],p[With a focus on delivering bold, enjoyable flavours, OAK continues to bring fun to flavoured milk, but now with an even stronger emphasis on efficiency —helping you stay energised and ready for whatever’s next.],h3[New Design Elements],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/oak/logo-breakdown.jpg{logo development;Logo development, modernising their current logo.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/NEW-colours.jpg{New colour palettes of OAK.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/NEW-brandkit.jpg{brand tool kit;New brand elements of OAK.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/NEW-styleg.jpg{styleguide;New OAK styleguide, rules for how to use the new branding elements.}]}],div[{h3[Bottle Designs]}{p[The new OAK bottle design preserves brand familiarity with a modernized logo and catchphrase while introducing an ergonomic shape for easy, on-the-go consumption. Its bold colour palette, dynamic typography, and energetic chip details replace traditional milk splashes, creating a more inclusive and high-energy visual identity that broadens its demographic appeal.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/oak/NEW-design-anal.jpg{bottle design;New bottle design analysis.}]}],div.small-gallery[{img[assets/proj/oak/NEW-bottle01.jpg{bottle design;New OAK chocolate bottle design.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/NEW-bottle02.jpg{bottle design;New OAK strawberry bottle design.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/NEW-bottle03.jpg{bottle design;New OAK vanilla bottle design.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/NEW-bottle04.jpg{bottle design;New OAK coffee bottle design.}]}],div[{h3[Carton Designs]}{p[For the bottles, using unconventional colours for the main part of the label works because of the bottle being transparent which informs the audience of what they are containing. To minimise confusion while staying consistent with the bottle-label, the carton design —which does not give this transparent insight to its content, clearly communicates its content by making the majority of the design in the colour of the actual milk.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/oak/NEW-carton.jpg{carton design;New carton design analysis.}]}],div.small-gallery[{img[assets/proj/oak/NEW-carton01.jpg{carton design;New OAK chocolate carton design.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/NEW-carton02.jpg{carton design;New OAK strawberry carton design.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/NEW-carton06.jpg{carton design;New OAK banana carton design.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/NEW-carton04.jpg{carton design;New OAK coffee carton design.}]}],h3[Other Packaging Designs],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/oak/OTHER-jug.jpg{jug design;New OAK jug designs.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/OTHER-box.jpg{box design;New 'instant OAK' box designs, with a mix of 'traditional' flavours, and more playful mixes of flavours (like the nepolitan).}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/OTHER-pouch.jpg{pouch design;New 'instant OAK' pouch designs.}]}],div[{h3[New OAK on the shelf]}{img.solo[assets/proj/oak/ALL-packages.jpg{product overview;All new OAK packaging designs.}]}],h2[POS and Marketing Campaign],p[OAK’s marketing strategy bridges digital and physical spaces with bold, energetic visuals that reinforce the rebrand across touchpoints. By balancing unconventional creativity with familiar formats, the campaign ensures strong brand recognition while engaging consumers in a more interactive and dynamic way.],h3[Point of sales],p[],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/oak/pos-wobble.jpg{shelf wobblers;Shelf wobblers bouncing with energy to grab customer's attention.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/pos-wobble-sit.jpg{shelf wobblers;Shelf wobblers in actual store.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/pos-vending.jpg{vending machine;Vending machine designs in different flavour themes, handing out stickers per OAK purchase (to plaster on vending machine or wherever you want.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/pos-vending-sit.jpg{vending machine;Vending machine at a University.}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/pos-cart.jpg{bike cart;Milk bar on wheels, a contemporary and dynamic version of OAK's historically iconic milk bar.}]}],div[{h3[Social Media]}{p[By weaving OAK’s relaunch campaign across social media and real-life touchpoints, the rebrand ensures a seamless, recognizable presence. Engaging digital content—like interactive campaigns and sponsored posts—primes consumers to notice OAK in physical spaces, from posters to POS displays. This repeated exposure strengthens brand familiarity, keeping OAK top-of-mind in everyday moments.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/oak/soME.jpg{soacial media; Highly active social media precense.}]}],h3[Sticker Campaign],p[{a[The Sticker Campaign;https://www.youtube.com/shorts/uvgvy5b2mXA]} playfully encourages consumers to spread OAK’s bold new identity by tagging their surroundings with dynamic logo variations. Strategically placed in high-traffic areas, the stickers turn brand interaction into a fun, cheeky, and participatory experience—strengthening the connection between OAK and its audience.],div[{img.solo[assets/proj/oak/sticker-campaign.jpg{campaign}]}],h3[Posters],p[Designed to catch the eye during busy commutes, OAK’s posters take a bold, unconventional approach—featuring cheeky messaging and playful cut-outs referencing the product without relying on traditional pack shots. This soft launch sparks curiosity, making the rebrand more recognizable when consumers later see the new product on shelves.],div[{img.solo[assets/proj/oak/posters.jpg{posters in street}]}],h3[Tram],p[A moving, high-impact ad that blends into the everyday routines of OAK’s target audience. With minimal text and oversized milk visuals, it grabs attention through bold simplicity, reinforcing brand recognition through familiarity with social media and poster layouts.],div[{img.solo[assets/proj/oak/oakTram.jpg{tram}]}],h3[Billboards],p[Strategically placed along high-traffic routes, OAK’s billboards use humor, low-fi stock imagery, and dynamic typography to disrupt the typical ad landscape. The playful composition makes them engaging at a glance while reinforcing OAK’s cheeky new identity, turning every sighting into a moment of brand recognition.],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/oak/billboard-choc.jpg{billboard on metro station}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/billboard-coff.jpg{billboard along highway}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/billboard-bana.jpg{billboard on metro station}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/billboard-vanilla.jpg{billboard next to pavement}]}{img[assets/proj/oak/billboard-strawb.jpg{billboard next to pavement}]}]
para8: div.reflection[{h1[Reflection]}{p[This project was an intense yet rewarding exercise in high-speed iteration, visual identity development, and ensuring brand values translated effectively into design. I gained valuable insights into marketing strategy and competitor analysis, strengthening my ability to position a brand within a crowded market.]}{p[From a teamwork perspective, this experience reinforced the importance of assertiveness in the design process. Initially, we tried to accommodate a nostalgic direction despite concerns about its effectiveness—leading to a last-minute shift. In hindsight, I would have been more vocal in questioning that direction earlier.]}{p[This project also pushed my creative problem-solving skills. When we found ourselves stuck in a visual rut, shifting perspectives and drawing inspiration from unexpected sources ultimately led to the bold, energetic design that successfully repositioned OAK.}{h2[If I did this again...]}{p[If I were to do this again, I’d trust my instincts sooner, challenge creative directions more directly, and lean my team even further into strategic, research-driven decision-making.]}]

overview: Designed and developed my personal portfolio website, creating a visual identity that reflects my work and personality. Built with a structured system that ensures an intuitive user experience and allows for effortless updates as my work evolves.
para0: div[{h1[Personal Portfolio]}{p-em[How do you design a portfolio that not only showcases your work but also reflects who you are—as both a designer and an individual? I built a personal website that integrates all my design skills, ensuring a modular and efficient structure for long-term scalability.]}],div[{h3[The challenge]}{p[A portfolio should showcase work effectively while remaining adaptable for future projects. I needed a system that would be visually engaging, easy to navigate, and simple to update without requiring major redesigns.]}{h3[My solution]}{p[A structured, scalable portfolio website designed for both impact and efficiency.]}{ul.col[Personal Visual Identity — A design that reflects my style, values, and approach to UX and graphic design.;User-Centric Experience — Intuitive navigation,content hierarchy and grouping to guide visitors seamlessly through my work.;Effortless Updates — A modular system that allows for easy content additions and adjustments, keeping the portfolio dynamic without disrupting consistency.;Self-Developed — Built from scratch to demonstrate my technical skillset alongside my design expertise.]}{h3[Impact]}{ul.col[A website that represents who I am as a designer through visuals and the structure of the design.;Maximising the total user interaction time with my website though playfull and quick-responsive interaction designs appealing to audience's attention/interest, making it fun to explore more of my page.]}]
para2: div[{h2[Discover: Portfolio trends]}{p[I examined UX and graphic design portfolios to identify trends in structure, content strategy, and visual style. UX portfolios prioritise clarity, case study depth, and intuitive navigation, whereas graphic design portfolios embrace bold visuals, conceptual storytelling, and experimental layouts. Below, I've gathered six portfolios that I liked and use as reference for my own layouts and content.]}],div.small-gallery[{img[assets/proj/folio/inspo/human.gif{table of projects;portfolio inspiration for projects}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/inspo/pk.jpg{project page;project page with neccessary contextual information}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/inspo/bekk.jpg{project page;project page of a consultancy firm I like}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/inspo/clairoux-stud.gif{split portfolio layout}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/inspo/refs.gif{reviews;Adding a review-section to add credibility to my work(ethic)}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/inspo/cover.jpg{landingpage}]}],div[{h3[Key Insights]}{ul.col[Balance industry-standard UX structures with graphic design’s dynamic creativity.;Align design with established UX portfolio trends—drawing from firms I admire and industry standards—automatically builds credibility.;Integrate the playful creativity of graphic design adding a dynamic edge, which ensures my portfolio is both intuitive for recruiters and uniquely engaging.]}],div[{h2[Who's reading this?]}{p[My portfolio is a way to showcase both my work and who I am as a designer to potential employers, recruiters, and UX professionals.]}{p[These audiences are often short on time, skimming through multiple portfolios, so my site needed to immediately communicate my skillset—both creative and analytical—while making their experience as effortless as possible.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/folio/branding/personas.png{3 cartoon faces}]}{h3[Key Insights]}{p[I needed to strike a balance between familiarity (ensuring my portfolio aligns with industry expectations) and individuality (standing out in a competitive field). This meant structuring the content intuitively while injecting enough personality to leave a lasting impression.]}]
para3: h2[Creating the Visual Identity],div[{h3[Brand Values & Personality]}{img.solo[assets/proj/folio/branding/values.png{brand values}]}{p[I'm a UX designer who centres her work in making useful designs that serves a purpose, tailored to the target audience's needs. I want the portfolio to embody a playfulness in its interactions, so my audience will have a fun experience when learning more about me and my work.]}{p[My focus on functionality, efficiency, accessibility and playfulness, creates a framework that allows me to explore the intersection of conceptuality and conventionality. That balance is what gives me and my work and personal branding an edge.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/folio/branding/pos.png{branding position}]}],div[{h3[Visual References]}{p[Taking inspiration from the utalitarity of brutalism and warmness of contemporary minimalistism, I've gathered different concepts, digital and printed references to tie together the brand's essence and website design.]}],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/folio/inspo/booklet.jpg{pamphlet design;Pamphlets and booklets are good at providing lots of information on narrow/smaller areas. Their efficient use of grid layouts and type sizes creates hierarchy that makes the information easy to digest.}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/inspo/margin-notes.jpg{book page with margin notes;Margins are often used to write/add extra information in books, will be useful for website to add contextual information to projects etc.}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/inspo/categorise.jpg{inventory table;Essentially, a portfolio is the same as a project inventory, I want to use tables with clear alignments to structure my project overview.}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/inspo/tags.jpg{tags list;Tags are a great way to sort information. With my multi-diciplinerian work, it would be benefitial to add structure based on types of work I've done.}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/inspo/fiver-branding.jpg{poster;Fiverr has a very conceptual and modern look to their brand typography. I love the contrast between the geometric sans serif and the curvier serif font.}]}],div[{h2[Brand Tool Kit]}{h3[Colour Palette]}{p[The portfolio carries a minimalistic colour palette with a white and black alternative for the primary colours. They are to be paired with the bright secondary colours for accent details, representing each service I provide.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/folio/branding/colour-pal.png{colour palette;Primary colours on the left, secondary to the right. These were all checked for colour contrast in order to stay accessible for vision impaired audiences.}]}],div[{h3[Typography]}{p[A sans serif for the primary type, making body texts, captions, hedlines etc legible, focusing on it being utilitarian. The secondary type is a rounded and modern serif, used as an accent type for emphasised informations.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/folio/branding/type.png{typography}]}],div[{h3[Logos]}{p[Created a logo that would represent the main 4 services I provide: UX, UI, service design, and conceptual design. This would be used as a back-to-home button on my website.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/folio/branding/logo-dev.png{logo development;Logo design thought process. Decided on the square as it matches the brutalism inspiration, and would represent the framework I work within while preserving the possibility of adding fun animations to ilustrate the playfulness of my work ethic.}]}],div.small-gallery[{img[assets/proj/folio/branding/logo-vars.png{squares;Logo variations}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/branding/logo-animation.gif{swquare animated;possible page-loading animation, or page-scroll animation for nav bar icon.}]}],div[{p[I also created a monogram to be used for the favicon in order to distinct my website from other websites/brands also using the square as their logo.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/folio/branding/mono-break.png{monogram breakdown;Monogram used as fav icon (far left), followed by illustrations demonstrating how the H, S, and B are represented in the design.}]}]
para4: div[{h2[Website Design Development]}{p[As the sole designer and developer for this project, the tight time frame made it neccessary to make quick design decisions and alterations. Therefore, I mostly relied on paper prototypes before coding it out, testing the layout details in VSCode itself and rarely made high fidelity prototypes. However, I used AdobeXD sometimes throughout the design process, checking how things would turn out as I went along.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/folio/des-dev/prototypes.png{design-to-code method}]}],div[{h3[Paper Prototypes with coding annotations]}{p[To make it easier for me to go from sketch to code, I annotated most wireframes to get an overview of how the HTML structure would be, as well as transitions, interactions, and design decisions.]}{img.solo[assets/proj/folio/des-dev/paper-prototypes.gif{sketches and notes}]}],div.small-gallery[{img[assets/proj/folio/des-dev/paper-prototype_1.jpg{full landing page}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/des-dev/paper-prototype_2.jpg{coverpage/landing}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/des-dev/paper-prototype_3.jpg{work archive}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/des-dev/paper-prototype_4.jpg{milestones}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/des-dev/paper-prototype_5.jpg{project page}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/des-dev/paper-prototype_6.jpg{mobile view}]}],div[{h3[AdobeXD file]}{p[I used the AdobeXD document a pin-up board, dynamically testing out some mid fidelity pototype variations and wireframes.]}],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/folio/des-dev/xd.png{file overview;Overview of XD file}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/des-dev/xd-code.png{file close-up;First design iteration of landing page layout, with annotations for transformations and interaction design}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/des-dev/xd-proj.png{file close-up;Design iterations of the project layouts with focus on displaying series of images in larger scales.}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/des-dev/xd-branding.png{file close-up;Used it as a pin-up board to check colours, how they looked next to each other etc. This is an early iteration of the current branding direction.}]}]
para5: h2[Coding Structure],p[I used a mix of HTML, CSS, and JS, with CSV databases to store project information and make it more seamless to update more projects in the future, while maintaining internal consistency. {ul.col[HTML: Set up page structure and fill in permanent information;CSS: Used a modular structure for easy access to layout/typography changes while keeping internal consistency;JS: For creating creative interactions and for parsing through and translating CSV data to populate website layouts;CSV: Database of project information]}{img.solo[assets/proj/folio/des-dev/files02.png{files}]}],div[{h2[Database Logic]}{p[I had two main databases that each were responsible for different things. Work-archive.csv populates the project archive table on the landing page (and allow for filter buttons to work). Projects.csv stores information for each project case study.]}{p[In order to connect the projects on the table view, with the case-study project pages, I needed to connect them with a primary key (project-id). With that, it was possible to use information from both to databases so I would not have to duplicate information (which can lead to an inconsistency problem when changing/updating the databases).]}{img.solo[assets/proj/folio/des-dev/data.png{infographic}]}]
para6: div[{h2[Final Designs]}{p[The final design is responsive, making it possible to audiences to visit the website from their preferred device.]}{p[Overall, it follows a strict grid layout with clear alignments in order to achieve a minimalist design for efficient reads, supporting the user's primary goals. And with focus on fun interactions and a consistent minimalist aesthetic, the visual design reinforces the audience's overall first impression of the portfolio, of me and of my credibility.]}],div.prototypes-mac[{img[assets/proj/folio/mock/comp/01landing.gif{mockup;Landing page with dynamic designer bio, explaining all the services I provide, along with a movable portrait to ensure readability and add touch of playfullness.}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/mock/comp/02archive.gif{mockup;Project archive with multi-handled hover functions with hero image appearing on hover as well as the background colour changing (that matches the project category (i.e. UX red, Service Green etc...). The filtering buttons also follow the same colour rulesets, and changes the table view based on what type of project / favourite projects.}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/mock/comp/06to-proj.gif{Mockup;Clicking on one of the projects in the work archive table redirects you to its respective in-depth presentation of each project.}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/mock/comp/07carousel.gif{mockup;Possible to change which image is in the spotlight by either key navigation or mouse-clicking.}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/mock/comp/08prototype.gif{mockup;Final Prototypes/Designs are styled differently than the other grouped-images, with a y-position transformation on selected (which happens either by mouse click or key navigation).}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/mock/comp/09proj-nav.gif{mockup;Easy navigation between projects in the margin, and exit oportunity in the top right square that redirects you back to the landing page.}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/mock/comp/03milestones.gif{mockup;Playful and responsive hover-interaction for each 'milestone polaroid'.}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/mock/comp/04revs.gif{mockup;Reviews of how I work and am to work with, taken from previous employers and lecturers.}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/mock/comp/05footer.gif{mockup;Footer designed as a business card, with kind personal greeting and links taking the audience to my CV, and redirecting them to my linkedIn for quick network connection opportunities.}]}],div[{h2[Design Decisions]}{p[The one-page scroll website contains of  essential information that a possible recruiter or client would be interested in knowing. The different sections are sorted in a hierarchy of importance/relevance, with the most essential information of me as a designer at the top —who I am, what projects I've made, followed up by nice-to haves like the milestones to indicate what iv'e done lately that is of notice, followed by information of how I work and how I am to work with. The footer is designed like a business card, with links to my linkedIn, my cv, and my email for people to get in touch. ]}],div.multi-carousel[{img[assets/proj/folio/des-dec/01land.png{annotated design;Aim: Design an eye catching yet minimalist introduction on who I am as a designer, with elements of the personal branding and playful interactions and animations.}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/des-dec/02archive.png{annotated design;Aim: Create a clear overview of all my projects with an efficient system to communicate what they are about, and what skilsets that are connected with them to make sure relevant information was accessible while skimming the list.}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/des-dec/03archive.png{annotated design;Aim: Adding a minimalist yet fun feedback system to encourage user interaction for  exploration of my projects.}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/des-dec/04mile.png{annotated design;Aim: Add a visual summary of relevant milestones that can also be read about on my cv for more engaging and memorable impression.}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/des-dec/05mile.png{annotated design;Aim: Fun feedback system to encourage user satisfaction and curiosity}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/des-dec/06rev+foot.png{annotated design;Aim: Giving insights to my work ethic and how I am would contribute to the work environment as a colleague, finishing off with leaving abusiness card encouraging for connection.}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/des-dec/07proj.png{annotated design;Aim: Clear overview of project, what it is about and entails. Fixed margin on the left of theproject page, with relevant context information on the project and for my role/contribution.}]}{img[assets/proj/folio/des-dec/08problem.png{annotated design;Should have a vertical navigation by the scroll bar to indicate the reader's location on the page and allow for snap navigation to other sections, but it is outside of my technical skills.}]}]
para7: div.reflection[{h1[Reflection]}{p[This project has been very exciting to work on, as it allowed me to use everything I learnt from my studies and put it into practice. By limiting myself to my own coding abilities, I've had to work in a tighter framework, creating and design solutions and structures that would be easy to maintain and update in the future.]}{p[The project has been a great learning experience, and I've had to make a lot of decisions on my own, which has been both challenging and rewarding. I've had to think about how to structure the content in a way that would be engaging and informative, while also being easy to navigate and update.]}{p[I truly enjoyed the entire design process of this project, and have discovered that this is a space I love to be and work in!]}{h2[In the works...]}{p[Like any other (a)live creature, the website is continously evolving and changing. Due to the tight time schedule on getting it up and running, there are some sections and interaction details that are in need of tweaking, and I also have more porjects that i'm currently writing to get up on the website. So stay tuned to more projects and updates!]}]
